#   coffee_b_personal_preference <dbl>, coffee_b_notes <chr>, …


The “Great American Coffee Taste Test” data set is compiled of survey results that were filled out by participants of a taste test, hosted in part by a coffee company Cometeer. Cometeer had sent 4 different types of coffee without labels to over 4,000 participants. The survey includes questions about coffee drinking habits, coffee preferences, individual taste test results for each of the 4 provides coffees, and individual demographics.
I chose this data set because I was curious about the demographics and preferences of coffee drinkers, both of customers of Cometeer and as a representation of the general North American population. My first question will look at coffee drinking habits (how many cups of coffee are drunken a day) and how they correlate with working and lifestyle situations (whether they work or not, if they work from home or not, and how many children they have). It could be interesting to further analyze that data with why they drink coffee (for the caffeine, or is it for the flavor?) or if that coffee is caffeinated or not, but I want to be careful of not introducing too many variables. Overall, my goal for the first question is to highlight a trend between coffee drinking and lifestyle that could be reflective of the general American population. As for my second question, I am taking a more “marketing” approach, as I will try to determine which type of coffee (in regards to strength, roast, and caffeine-level) is most popular among Cometeer customers, as this information could assist them with product development.

title: A Coffee Drinker’s Lifestyle
text:
Questions
The two questions* I want to answer:

How do coffee drinking habits correlate with working and lifestyle situations?
What combinations of coffee characteristics are the most popular?

* Because this is a solo project, I only need to answer 1 question. For now, I will be attempting to answer both of these, but prioritizing Question 1, with Question 2 acting as a back up option (I initially thought we needed two questions).

title: A Coffee Drinker’s Lifestyle
text:
Analysis plan
A plan for answering each of the questions including the variables involved, variables to be created (if any), external data to be merged in (if any).

Variables: cups, employment_status, number_children, wfh, age

I plan to create a grouped bar plot, of the count of amount of cups drunken per day (“cups”), which will be grouped by position for work status (“employment_status”) and then color will indicate work from home status (“wfh”). I will also incorporate number of children (“number_children”) into this grouped bar plot, perhaps by faceting.
As mentioned, I want to find a way to incorporate number of children (“number_children”), as raising children is a form of labor and should be considered in lifestyle situations, but the number of children may not accurately reflect how many are dependents. To address this, I will create a scatter plot, with number of children against number of cups per day, coloring by age. Incorporating “age” may further explain any trends (a 30 year old with children is more likely to have them in their home versus a 60 year old with children, although this may be an inappropriate generalization to make and I will play around with the data.) (addressing issue #1)

Variables: strength, roast_level, caffeine, value_equipment, value_cafe

To make it easier to visualize, I will mutate the “strength”, “roast_level”, and “caffeine” variables from categorical to numeric variables, assigning an appropriate number scale (for example, 1-5 for “Weak” to “Very strong” strength). I then intend to create a contour plot of the three variables, visualizing what combination of the three is the most popular coffee consumed. This could be helpful to know for Cometeer, which coffee could be the most profitable to produce.
To further explore popularity, I will explore the 3 most popular coffee combinations and compare against the value of home-made (“value_equipment”) and cafe-bought coffee (“value_cafe”) in a bar plot, faceting by the different coffee types (addressing issue #2).

Studies have shown that lifestyle and demographic factors influence intake (Loftfield et al. 2016)

What are the correlations between coffee consumption and lifestyle?

title: Coffee Drinking Habits and Working Lifestyle
section: The “Great American Coffee Taste Test” data set
text:
The “Great American Coffee Taste Test” data set

Survey results filled out by taste test participants, co-hosted by U.S.-based coffee company Cometeer. (tracykteal 2024)
The survey includes questions about coffee drinking habits, coffee preferences, individual taste test results for each of the 4 provided coffees, and individual demographics.


Image credit: Cometeer, cometeer.com (Cometeer Logo Image, n.d.).

All Variables Accounted For
Average amount of coffee ranges between 1 and 3 cups

title: Coffee Drinking Habits and Working Lifestyle
Coffee Drinking Habits and Working Lifestyle
text:
Conclusion

Average cups of coffee ranges between 1 - 3 cups for each group

title: Coffee Drinking Habits and Working Lifestyle
text:
Conclusion

Average cups of coffee ranges between 1 - 3 cups for each group
Drinking less than 1 cup of coffee is more common among those less than 24 years old, no kids, and unemployed.
Drinking more than average is more common among those 45 years old and older, with many kids, and retired.

title: Coffee Drinking Habits and Working Lifestyle
text:
Conclusion

Average cups of coffee ranges between 1 - 3 cups for each group
Drinking less than 1 cup of coffee is more common among those less than 24 years old, no kids, and unemployed.
Drinking more than average is more common among those 45 years old and older, with many kids, and retired.
Future work should consider the weight of age on coffee drinking habits or correlation between factors - what truly has a weight on these habits?

title: Coffee Drinking Habits and Working Lifestyle
text:
References








Cometeer Logo Image. n.d. cometeer.com.


Loftfield, Erikka, Neal D Freedman, Kevin W Dodd, Emily Vogtmann, Qian Xiao, Rashmi Sinha, and Barry I Graubard. 2016. “Coffee Drinking Is Widespread in the United States, but Usual Intake Varies by Key Demographic and Lifestyle Factors.” The Journal of Nutrition 146 (9): 1762–68. https://doi.org/10.3945/jn.116.233940.


tracykteal. 2024. “The Great American Coffee Taste Test.” https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2024/2024-05-14/readme.md.

title: About
text: This project was developed by Vera Soloview Jackson For INFO 526 - Data Analysis and Visualization at the University of Arizona, taught by Dr. Greg Chism. Vera is in her first year of the Master’s of Science in Data Science program at the University of Arizona.
